review.star_rating: Rated 4 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: On the whole I really like it, a tidy UI and simple to use, as well as secure and encrypted between two signal users. You need to be on wifi/mobile data to be able to send messages to a friend you've established signal contact with. it won't tell you that the message can't be or hasn't been sent. Get in the habit of checking connectivity before sending, and decide if you want to use insecure SMS, as it's a simple enough switch on the send button. They've not got the UX case handled if your friend uninstalls or stops using it either, it needs to default back to SMS If it can be detected. It's also very fussy with the international phone number formats - even if your friend phones you so it's the number that is registered without you entering it by hand, you have to edit. But apart from that, it's great. Head and shoulders above anything else I've tried, plus secure.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: Excellent texting app, the encryption is totally seamless, no user set-up required. Just want to acknowledge the uphill battle the devs have so marvellously won - not only is this the most secure texting app on the market, but it competes with and exceeds most other texting apps. Download it, you won't be disappointed. Update: the encrypted calls lag by about three seconds. If your first concern is a private conversation, it'll do, but it's not really a drop-in replacement for regular calls.

review.review_title: Signal is the gold standard for secure messaging
review.review_text: Security analysts recently discovered that WhatsApp owner Facebook has created backdoors in WhatsApp that give them & others the ability to intercept and read messages made using WhatsApp. If you need to be sure your messages are secure; if your safety, life, livelihood or business depends on your messages being secure then Signal is the only app for the job. It's initial set up is simple, you don't need a degree in cryptography to use it and it's code is under constant review to make sure it's secure.

review.star_rating: Rated 4 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: Gold Standard of Secure Private Messaging
review.review_text: Super easy to setup and use. End to end encryption is awesome and takes your mind off of having to self censor. Being able to use it as a complete sms app replacement is great. It has room to grow in functionality to other apps, such as BBM, which has nice features like being able to send multiple attachments per message. That being said there is no other app that brings this level of privacy in such an easy package. That's what makes this the gold standard at the moment.

review.star_rating: Rated 3 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: I like that it's secure, but it definitely has some drawbacks. Sometimes when I open Signal, it takes a while (several minutes, at least) for it to load in the names and pictures -- and while I wait, it just shows me the phone numbers. I hardly recognize any phone numbers, so I never know who sent what until it eventually loads the names. It does this on several other phones in my family, too. Secondly, it doesn't support Cell Broadcast, so when an emergency broadcast (e.g., Amber Alert or other alert) is sent out, I have to go back to the regular messaging app to view it. No reason Signal shouldn't be able to support CB.

My biggest gripe with the service is that I would love to see a true (non-chrome) web/desktop UI as well. I'm looking to replace the functionality of Google Hangouts, and apart from video calling, my most-missed feature is true cross-device access to the platform.

review.star_rating: Rated 2 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: Doesn't do it's primary job - sending texts to contacts
review.review_text: I used to love this third party alternative to the less-than-stellar Android or Samsung messaging default until I realized people weren't getting my texts. Coworkers and private relationships have been tarnished because the texts I sent out never reached the intended recipient! I'd like to see improvements on backup/import (media and auto backup) and Google Now.

review.star_rating: Rated 3 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: Needs to handle bad connection better
review.review_text: My wife and I are testing signal out, using it for SMS as well as encrypted messages. Sometimes if one of us has a patchy internet connection then we don't receive messages until the sender connects to Wi-Fi (sometimes hours later). I would like there to be better feedback for the sender in these cases (who is often unaware that the message has not been received) & an easy option to send an (unencrypted) sms if a message does not deliver. Security is important but reliability and transparencyoften more so.

review.review_text: I have not quite figured out the notification settings, and most of my acquaintances have no idea what this means, but it works well, so far as I know, with the dozen or so people who use it. I am committed to enlisting everyone to move over to this type of unsnoopable communication, in light of the NSA revelations that each and every person in the world is intended to be surveilled, with no other cause, in all of their forms of communication. To honor the lives of others.

review.star_rating: Rated 4 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: Good stuff. But remember to manually export your messages from within the app, if doing (eg) ROM flashing which requires wiping your phone. Signal doesn't use the Android system messages DB, so a normal ADB Backup won't save them. I learnt this the hard way and lost a couple of hundred messages! This also applies when switching back to another SMS app. Any SMS you sent using Signal won't be imported back into the system messages DB, so if you need them, you'll have to manually export/import them.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: Snowden approved! Bruce Schneier approved! Best part, though, might be that it is a better messing app than the stock Android messaging. It handles group messaging properly. It sends regular SMS/MMS to people in your contact list that don't have Signal, and secure messaging for people that do. Plus it syncs messages with the desktop version or other multiple devices you have. There is absolutely no reason for anyone on Android not to immediately install this. Improve your security and privacy today!

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: This app would be terrific except for one problem. I have the phone sitting there with Wi-Fi or mobile, strong signal, and volume up. I am expecting my wife to send something but I get nothing. I grab the phone to look, only to find there is no notification. I open the app and suddenly it goes bing! and shows me a new message, sent 18 minutes ago. I was here the whole time. What happened? This keeps randomly happening. When this happens, FB messenger is not having any issue. I don't think there is a net issue. What's worse, it shows the message as received to the other person, so I think it went through, but its off in la la land somewhere deciding to show up a random amount of time later. Very bad for communicating, just causes arguments with people talking past each other, with no idea that they are getting delayed.

review.review_text: It's a good app, as such things go. I trust my conversations on here to be private far more than I trust other apps which have implemented Open Whisper, like Facebook and WhatsApp. It does bother me, however, that your account is tied to your phone number. Phone numbers are some of the most traceable identifiers on the planet, and would therefore seem to work against the concept of a totally private messaging experience. It feels like a different, more anonymous unique identifier would be possible.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: I know someone who lives in a cell service desert, whose only chances of outside communication is through their landline or their iffy internet connection. She was given an iPad and was delighted to be able to text other Apple owners without much issue at all, but was frustrated at her inability to text Android users. A lot of apps that work across both operating systems are questionable, but this one is decidedly the least offensive when it comes to privacy and security. It works beautifully as well.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: I am a long-time user of this app and Signal is a great, easy-to-use encrypted messenger with continually expanding features that has a very good reputation amongst the FOSS and privacy-concerned communities. I have just a few requests for features to be added: (1) a doodling feature like is available on apps like Wire or iMessage, (2) encrypted video calls, and (3) the ability to like or edit messages already sent. I would be interested in knowing if OWS plans to implement these in the future and when.

review.star_rating: Rated 5 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_text: There are a lot of well-marketed encryption solutions out there, but what most don't know is that these are generally not very strong, nor well-regarded by cryptography researchers. Signal is the real deal. The protocol is well-regarded and publically available, and considered a model when new standards for encrypted communication are discussed. I've read the spec and believe it to guarantee that both the servers themselves cannot read your messages, and that the client can prove they've been delivered.

review.review_text: As simple as that. Signal seems to take privacy to the point of deciding I myself can't view some messages sent to me, tossing them down the memory hole, never to be retrieved. I could somewhat understand this as a rather aggressive security measure, but only if the app deigned to let me read what I'm sent first. A glaring flaw in what is otherwise an excellent, indispensable tool. Also, it'd be nice to have a few more colours to choose from.

review.star_rating: Rated 1 star_ratings out of five star_ratings
review.review_title: Unreliable and Devs Refuse to Fix
review.review_text: This app has two issues 1 i can live with and one I cannot. 1) Messages won't send over WiFi. 2) when delivering messages the phone sometimes give delivery error messages that seem to be untrue. In my own testing the issues seem to be that the the app doesn't play well with iMessage. The Debug system they use can't capture the issue so for them it doesn't exist. Their answer is to turn off notifications for all message so I never have delivery confirmation. I say fix the app. They say no.
